w.note: Ѥфрантъ and Ѥфратъ (both also with Ѥв– and Ѥѵ–) are attested early as representations of Euphrates. We retain the spelling in the manuscript.
Тх reads ини here, which makes sense, so we follow the manuscript and reject Tvorogov’s unnecessary ementation to они.
Digenis refers to himself as My Nothingness, a play on words with the style of address to the Emperor as Твоѥ Цѣсарьство Your Highness.
Tvorogov emends поведати to побѣдити and we follow.
The manuscript reading has a Gsg possessive pronoun modifying a Dsg noun. Either case is possible in this context, but the combination is incorrect, and we emend (somewhat arbitrarily) to Gsg.
That is, he accepted Digenis’s messenger.
There is no indirect object in Тх; we follow Tvorogov in emending to insert a reference to the Emperor.
